example.gov: The official municipal portal is available at www.example.gov.

requirements: Applicants should complete all steps outlined in the startup checklist before submitting.
Ensure your checklist includes proof of insurance, photos, and valid identification.

license guide: Refer to the provincial guide to license your business, which includes timelines and fees.
This guide provides instructions on how to apply for operational licenses online.

regulations: All vendors must adhere to local bylaws regarding hours of operation and public conduct.

fine: Failure to comply with the licensing conditions may result in a fine of up to $5,000.
Repeat violations are subject to increased penalties.

provincial license: A valid provincial business license must be obtained before operations commence.

food license: Provincial food business licenses are issued by the Department of Health and Safety.

municipal license: Municipal business licenses are required in addition to provincial registration.

food vendor permit: Vendors must obtain a municipal food business license from the local authority.

retail permit: Retailers selling consumer packaged goods must hold a retail license for CPG sales.

street vending: Curbside vending is only permitted in designated municipal zones.

fees: Vendors operating in downtown areas are subject to daily parking fees.

noise restriction: All operators must comply with noise bylaws restricting amplified sound after 10 PM.

traffic control: Traffic bylaws require food trucks to park at least 10 meters from intersections.

hours: Permitted operation hours for vendors are between 7 AM and 9 PM.

branding: Vendors may sell branded consumer goods if they are pre-packaged and labeled correctly.

private property: Operation on private property requires written permission from the property owner.

distance rule: Vendors must comply with proximity regulations set by municipal zoning authorities.

restaurant distance: A minimum distance of 25 meters must be maintained from any existing restaurant.

truck distance: Each food truck must be located at least 50 meters from another food truck.

non-food proximity: Proximity restrictions apply to non-food services like retail carts or kiosks.

business distance: A distance of at least 15 meters is required from other operating businesses.

limit: The number of food trucks allowed in each designated area is capped at ten.

location: Designated parking locations are marked on the municipal map for vendors.

restrictions: Private landlords may impose additional restrictions beyond city bylaws.

authority: The local authority responsible is the City of Riverview Licensing Office.

link: Contact or apply directly at https://riverview.gov/licensing.

insurance: All operators must maintain liability insurance with a minimum coverage of $2 million.

truck specifications: Trucks must have a minimum hand washing station and waste disposal unit.

appearance: Exterior appearance guidelines require a clean, professional look with no offensive graphics.
